If all humans had the ability to become invisible at will, society would have to adapt to the new normal of having people who could potentially disappear without a trace. This could lead to a decrease in crime rates as criminals would be less likely to commit crimes if they knew they could be easily caught. However, it could also lead to a decrease in trust among people as it would be harder to identify and verify the identity of others. Confidence score: 0.7

Invisible people could potentially have an advantage in certain professions such as spying, espionage, and surveillance. However, this could also lead to a loss of privacy and security as people could be spied on without their knowledge. Confidence score: 0.6

Invisible people could also have an advantage in certain physical activities such as sports and exercise, as they would not be visible to others and could move more freely. However, this could also lead to a loss of social interaction and connection as people would not be able to see or communicate with others while they are invisible. Confidence score: 0.5

Invisible people could potentially have an advantage in certain social situations such as parties and gatherings, as they could move around unnoticed and observe others without being seen. However, this could also lead to a loss of personal identity and self-expression as people would not be able to see themselves or express themselves through their appearance. Confidence score: 0.4

Invisible people could potentially have an advantage in certain professions such as medicine and surgery, as they could operate on patients without being seen and potentially reduce the risk of contamination.
